description: goprotobuf: Update .hgtags to cover the latest bug fixes.

messages.text:
Is this the protobuf version you want people using
with that release of Go?  Then yes.

On Fri, Sep 23, 2011 at 1:00 PM, Russ Cox <rsc@golang.org> wrote:

> On Thu, Sep 22, 2011 at 22:08, David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org> wrote:
>> Okay. This use of tags is a little different to what the concept
>> normally means in version control systems. It works for Mercurial, but
>> Git is going to get grumpy. Oh, well.
>
> I thought the whole point of git was that it gives
> you the building blocks to do whatever you want.
> Sad that Mercurial is more powerful.

It gives you a thing called "branches". Tags are meant to be applied
once, and stay still.

Mercurial doesn't have real tags, per se, since you can't reference
them if the .hgtags file in whatever revision you happen to have
checked out doesn't mention it. That's the biggest downside of storing
VCS metadata inside the VCS itself.


Dave.

Hello adg (cc: golang-dev@googlegroups.com),

I'd like you to review this change to
https://goprotobuf.googlecode.com/hg

A meta-question is, is this the right thing to be doing, namely
updating tags as long as the code stays compatible with the relevant
release?


Dave.

On Fri, Sep 23, 2011 at 12:05 PM, Russ Cox <rsc@golang.org> wrote:

> Is this the protobuf version you want people using
> with that release of Go?  Then yes.

Okay. This use of tags is a little different to what the concept
normally means in version control systems. It works for Mercurial, but
Git is going to get grumpy. Oh, well.

*** Submitted as http://code.google.com/p/goprotobuf/source/detail?r=b66abe622bd3 ***

goprotobuf: Update .hgtags to cover the latest bug fixes.

R=adg, rsc
CC=golang-dev
http://codereview.appspot.com/5079047

On Thu, Sep 22, 2011 at 23:09, David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org> wrote:
> Mercurial doesn't have real tags

s/real/Git's/

On Thu, Sep 22, 2011 at 22:08, David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org> wrote:
> Okay. This use of tags is a little different to what the concept
> normally means in version control systems. It works for Mercurial, but
> Git is going to get grumpy. Oh, well.

I thought the whole point of git was that it gives
you the building blocks to do whatever you want.
Sad that Mercurial is more powerful.

subject: code review 5079047: goprotobuf: Update .hgtags to cover the latest bug fixes.
